metadata.titleEn: Multi-scale surface flux and meteorological elements observation dataset in the Hai River Basin (Huailai station-lysimeters, 2014)
metadata.description:
The dataset contains the observation data of evapotranspiration apparatus on January 1, 2014, solstice, December 31, 2014.The site is located in huailai county, hebei province, east garden town, the underlying surface for corn.The latitude and longitude of the observation point is 115.7880E, 40.3491N, and the altitude is 480m.
The collection frequency of evapotranspiration permeameter is 1 time/minute, and the released data is the average of 10 minutes.The evapotranspiration meter is a cylindrical structure with a surface area of 1m2 and a buried depth of 1.5m. The observation accuracy of evapotranspiration is 0.01mm.Two evapotranspiration seeptometers were installed, one kept bare soil (lysimeter_1), the other for the corn underlay (lysimeter_2) during the growing season (May 10 - September 15).Soil temperature and humidity probe, soil water potential probe and soil heat flow plate are also installed in the evapotranspiration apparatus.The buried depth of the soil temperature sensor is 5cm, 30cm, 50cm, 100cm and 140cm.The buried depth of the soil water sensor is 2cm, 10cm, 20cm and 40cm.The soil heat flux plate is buried 10cm underground;The buried depth of the soil water potential sensor was 30cm and 140cm.Processing and quality control of observation data :(1) ensure 144 data per day (every 10min). If data is missing, it will be marked by -6999;(2) delete the data of observation anomalies caused during maintenance;(3) data that is obviously beyond the physical meaning or the range of the instrument is deleted;(4) the format of date and time is unified, and the date and time are in the same column.For example, the time is: 2014-6-10-10:30.
The observation data released by the evapotranspiration permeameter include:Date/Time, weighing mass (i.l._1_wag_l_000 (Kg), i.l._2_wag_l_000 (Kg)), seepage mass (i.l._1_wag_d_000 (Kg), i.l._2_wag_d_000 (Kg)), soil heat flux (Gs_1_10cm, Gs_2_10cm) (W/m2),Multi-layer soil moisture (Ms_1_2cm, Ms_1_10cm, Ms_1_20cm, Ms_1_40cm, Ms_2_2cm, Ms_2_10cm, Ms_2_20cm, Ms_2_40cm) (%),Multi-layer soil temperature (Ts_1_5cm, Ts_1_30cm, Ts_1_50cm, Ts_1_100cm, Ts_1_140cm, Ts_2_140cm, ts_2_2_5cm, ts_2_2_50cm, Ts_2_100cm, Ts_2_140cm) (℃), soil water potential (TS_1_30 (hPa), TS_1_140 (hPa), TS_2_30 (hPa), TS_2_30 (hPa), TS_2_140 (hPa), TS_2_140 (hPa));The data is stored in *.xls format.
Please refer to Yang guangchao et al. (2015) for observation test or site introduction, and refer to Liu et al. (2013) for data processing.

Data usage: this data is tabular data, which can be opened and viewed by WPS, Ecxel and other software

background: Based on the measurements of lysimeter, eddy covariance (EC), and automatic weather station (AWS) in Huailai Remote Sensing Experiment Station in 2012 and 2013, the daily and seasonal variation of soil evaporation and maize field evapotranspiration have been analyzed. The relationship between field evapotranspiration and meteorological factors (net radiation, air temperature, air humidity, and wind speed), soil moisture has been studied through multiple regression analysis method. Lysimeter’s representativeness was significantly affected by the growth of the crops within it. As heat can not be exchanged between the soil in lysimeter and the soil outside, the average temperature of the soil in the lysimeter is 9.5% higher than that of the field outside.
research objective: This article utilizes observation data from the evaporation and infiltration instrument at the Chinese Academy of Sciences Remote Sensing Comprehensive Experimental Station in Huailai, Hebei, from May to September in 2012 and 2013. It calculates soil evaporation, crop evapotranspiration, rainfall, and leakage during the corn growing season. By combining meteorological factors, it explores the daily and seasonal variation patterns of soil evaporation and crop evapotranspiration. Additionally, it compares and analyzes the observation results of evapotranspiration from the eddy covariance instrument and the evaporation and infiltration instrument to verify the representativeness of the latter. It also preliminarily analyzes the reasons for the differences between the two, providing a reference for future research on agricultural irrigation decision-making and water-saving in agriculture.
challenges: The evaporation and infiltration instrument is a single-point observation tool with a limited observation range, resulting in limited spatial representativeness. Therefore, it is essential to verify whether the observation results of the evaporation and infiltration instrument can represent the evapotranspiration values of farmland within the regional scope. Even after energy closure correction, the evapotranspiration measured by the eddy covariance instrument is lower than that of the evaporation and infiltration instrument, which shows an overestimation phenomenon. Strong Xiaoman and others believe that the evaporation and infiltration instrument interrupts the water and heat exchange with the surrounding farmland, leading to differences in soil moisture supply and heat exchange within the instrument compared to the surrounding farmland, which may cause the overestimation of evapotranspiration by the evaporation and infiltration instrument.
methods: To study the variation characteristics of farmland evapotranspiration in the North China region, a multi-scale evapotranspiration observation system was set up in the study area. The experimental area is divided into irrigated land and dry land by the red line shown in the figure. Both the irrigated land and dry land are equipped with a 10 m meteorological tower and a 40 m meteorological tower, which are installed with automatic weather stations and eddy covariance instruments. The soil moisture and energy balance systems are installed at the 10 m meteorological tower located in the irrigated land. According to the experimental requirements, one of the two soil moisture instruments remains bare soil for comparison, while the other is planted with corn. To ensure that the growth conditions of corn in the soil moisture instrument are consistent with those of the surrounding farmland corn during the experiment, corn of the variety Zhengdan 958 was planted on one of the soil moisture instruments on May 5, 2012, and May 10, 2013, with the same sowing time, row spacing, and plant spacing as the surrounding farmland. Additionally, regular weeding was conducted in the soil moisture instrument to ensure that the growth of corn inside the instrument was as consistent as possible with that of the surrounding farmland.
dataset: The evaporation and infiltration instrument used in this study is a weighing lysimeter produced by the German company UMS, model Hydro-Lysimeter. It was installed on September 11, 2011, in a field located about 300 meters east of the experimental station, approximately 10 meters from the external road. The lysimeter has a cylindrical structure with a surface area of 1 m² and a height of 1.5 m, with an evaporation measurement accuracy of 0.1 mm. The two lysimeters share a maintenance well, which is equipped with two leakage buckets for measuring the leakage amount, with a measurement accuracy of 0.01 mm. Additionally, both lysimeters are equipped with sensors for soil water potential, soil temperature, soil moisture, and soil heat flux.
findings: The result shows that the daily variation curves of soil evaporation were quite consistent with maize field evapotranspiration, while seasonal differences were obvious. In the region of Huailai, net radiation and soil moisture obviously correlated with daily evapotranspiration, while other factors did not obviously correlate. The correlativity between evapotranspiration measured by EC and that by lysimeter is very good. The value of lysimeter is 10.5% higher than that of EC. As a result, the evapotranspiration of lysimeter is relatively larger.

Disjunctive.Question: Which factor is more influential in affecting the accuracy of lysimeter data: soil moisture differences, net radiation discrepancies, or the isolation of lysimeter soil from surrounding fields?
Disjunctive.Answer: The isolation of lysimeter soil from surrounding fields

Concept Completion.Question: What are the primary data collection methods used for observing soil evaporation and crop evapotranspiration in the Huailai region?
Concept Completion.Answer: lysimeters, eddy covariance systems, automatic weather stations

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to measure soil evaporation and evapotranspiration in agricultural fields?
Example.Answer: One example of a data collection method used to measure soil evaporation and evapotranspiration is the use of lysimeters, which are installed to monitor soil moisture, temperature, and heat flux at various depths. In the field described, lysimeters were used to observe the daily and seasonal variation of soil evaporation and maize field evapotranspiration in Huailai, integrating meteorological factors and soil moisture data.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of how a research approach was used to study the relationship between evapotranspiration and meteorological factors in a specific region?
Example.Answer: A research approach used to study the relationship between evapotranspiration and meteorological factors involved multiple regression analysis in the Huailai region. This approach analyzed the correlation of field evapotranspiration with factors such as net radiation, air temperature, air humidity, wind speed, and soil moisture. The findings indicated that net radiation and soil moisture were significantly correlated with daily evapotranspiration in this region.

Feature Specification.Answer: high-frequency measurements, 10-minute averages, limited spatial representation, potential for overestimating evapotranspiration, requires careful quality control

Definition.Question: What challenges are associated with using lysimeters for data collection in agricultural research?
Definition.Answer: Challenges associated with using lysimeters include their limited spatial representativeness due to being single-point observations, and their potential to overestimate evapotranspiration values. The lysimeter can isolate soil from its surroundings, leading to differences in water and heat exchange compared to the surrounding field, which may result in discrepancies in measured evapotranspiration. It is necessary to verify whether lysimeter observations can accurately represent field-scale evapotranspiration values.

Comparison.Question: How does the data collection method using a lysimeter compare to using an eddy covariance system in terms of accuracy and representativeness of evapotranspiration measurements?
Comparison.Answer: Lysimeter measurements are affected by the isolation from surrounding soil, which can lead to higher temperature and potentially overestimated evapotranspiration values compared to eddy covariance systems. The eddy covariance system, despite energy closure corrections, tends to show lower evapotranspiration values than the lysimeter.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in spatial representativeness between datasets collected using lysimeters versus automatic weather stations (AWS) in agricultural field studies?
Comparison.Answer: Lysimeters provide point-specific data with limited spatial representativeness, whereas AWS can cover broader areas, allowing for more comprehensive data collection on meteorological factors affecting agricultural fields.

Comparison.Question: In terms of measuring soil moisture and temperature, how does the sensor depth positioning in a lysimeter setup compare to traditional field-based meteorological towers?
Comparison.Answer: Lysimeter setups often have sensors positioned at multiple soil depths (e.g., 5cm to 140cm) to capture detailed soil moisture and temperature profiles, whereas meteorological towers typically focus on above-ground atmospheric conditions, providing different types of environmental data.

Interpretation.Question: What can the observed differences between evapotranspiration values measured by eddy covariance systems and lysimeters reveal about the physical processes occurring in agricultural environments?
Interpretation.Answer: The differences in evapotranspiration values observed between eddy covariance systems and lysimeters may highlight the physical processes of heat and moisture exchange. The lysimeter tends to show higher evapotranspiration values due to its isolation from surrounding soil, suggesting that soil moisture and heat dynamics are altered within the lysimeter compared to the surrounding field.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways do the installation and configuration of sensors within a lysimeter influence the accuracy and reliability of soil moisture and temperature measurements?
Interpretation.Answer: The installation of sensors at various depths within a lysimeter, such as soil temperature sensors at 5 cm to 140 cm and soil moisture sensors at multiple shallow depths, provides comprehensive data on soil conditions. This configuration helps ensure accurate and reliable measurements by capturing vertical variations in soil properties, though it also requires careful calibration and quality control to address potential anomalies or biases.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the representativeness of lysimeter measurements to vary significantly when analyzing field evapotranspiration?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Lysimeter's representativeness is significantly affected by the growth of crops within it because heat cannot be exchanged between the soil in the lysimeter and the soil outside, leading to a higher average temperature inside the lysimeter compared to the field.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why might lysimeter measurements of evapotranspiration be higher compared to those from eddy covariance systems?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Lysimeter measurements might be higher because the system isolates soil from surrounding conditions, affecting water and heat exchange, which can result in an overestimation of evapotranspiration compared to eddy covariance systems.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the limited spatial representativeness of lysimeter observations in agricultural fields?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Lysimeters provide single-point observations with a small observation range, and their isolation from surrounding fields can limit their spatial representativeness and affect the generalization of evapotranspiration values to larger field areas.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the implications of using a lysimeter with limited spatial representation for understanding regional evapotranspiration patterns?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using a lysimeter for single-point observations limits spatial representation and raises questions about whether its results can represent evapotranspiration values across a broader agricultural area. This limitation necessitates verification of its observations for regional applicability, as the isolated conditions within the lysimeter can lead to differences in soil moisture and heat exchange compared to surrounding fields.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the presence of crops within a lysimeter affect the accuracy of evapotranspiration measurements compared to surrounding fields?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The presence of crops within a lysimeter affects the accuracy of evapotranspiration measurements because it disrupts the natural exchange of heat and moisture with the environment, causing the soil inside the lysimeter to have a higher average temperature by 9.5% compared to the outside field. This can result in an overestimation of evapotranspiration values when compared to measurements from eddy covariance systems.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using different data collection systems, such as lysimeters and eddy covariance, on the observed evapotranspiration values?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using different data collection systems like lysimeters and eddy covariance can lead to discrepancies in observed evapotranspiration values. For instance, lysimeter measurements tend to be higher than those from eddy covariance due to the lack of heat exchange with surrounding soil, which can affect water and heat supply dynamics. Despite energy closure corrections, eddy covariance might report lower evapotranspiration, highlighting the need for cross-verification and understanding the systematic differences between the methods.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the key objectives of implementing multi-scale evapotranspiration observation systems in agricultural research areas?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to study the characteristics of farmland evapotranspiration in the North China region, assessing daily and seasonal variations in soil evaporation and maize field evapotranspiration, as well as understanding the relationship with meteorological factors like net radiation and soil moisture. This research supports agricultural irrigation decision-making and water-saving strategies.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to compare the evapotranspiration measurements from different instruments like lysimeters and eddy covariance systems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Comparing these measurements is crucial to verify the representativeness and accuracy of the lysimeter observations, which tend to overestimate evapotranspiration due to isolated conditions that differ from surrounding fields. This comparison helps in understanding the discrepancies and improving the reliability of evapotranspiration data for broader agricultural applications.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods can be used to ensure the accuracy and reliability of lysimeter data collection for soil and crop evapotranspiration studies?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The accuracy and reliability of lysimeter data collection can be ensured by implementing a robust data processing and quality control protocol, which includes ensuring daily data completeness, removing anomalies caused by maintenance, and deleting data that exceeds physical or instrumental limits. Regular calibration of sensors and cross-validation with other instruments like eddy covariance can also enhance data reliability.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is the installation of lysimeters and associated sensors configured to capture comprehensive soil and atmospheric data in agricultural settings?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Lysimeters are installed with a cylindrical structure and a surface area of 1m², buried to a depth of 1.5m. They are equipped with soil temperature sensors at various depths, soil moisture sensors, soil heat flow plates, and soil water tension sensors. The sensors are strategically placed to capture different layers of soil conditions, ensuring a thorough data collection of both soil and atmospheric factors.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What steps are involved in setting up a multi-scale evapotranspiration observation system in a research area to study agricultural water use efficiency?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To set up a multi-scale evapotranspiration observation system, the research area is divided into irrigated and dryland sections, each equipped with meteorological towers and instruments like eddy covariance and automatic weather stations. Lysimeters are installed in irrigated sections, with one left bare and another planted with crops like maize to ensure comparable growth conditions. Regular maintenance and calibration ensure accurate data collection.

Enablement.Question: What methodologies enable researchers to accurately control and compare soil conditions within and outside a lysimeter to ensure representative data collection?
Enablement.Answer: Researchers use multiple regression analysis to study the relationship between evapotranspiration and meteorological factors, ensuring that lysimeter data is compared with field data. Additionally, to maintain consistency in soil conditions, crops in lysimeters are planted with the same variety, spacing, and timing as surrounding fields, and regular maintenance such as weeding is conducted.

Enablement.Question: Which technological tools are crucial for enhancing the precision of evapotranspiration measurements in agricultural research settings?
Enablement.Answer: The use of dual lysimeters, eddy covariance systems, and automatic weather stations are crucial for precise evapotranspiration measurements. These tools allow for comprehensive monitoring of soil moisture, temperature, and heat flux, providing data that is critical for understanding soil and crop interactions.

Enablement.Question: How do soil moisture and meteorological sensor placements within a lysimeter facilitate detailed data collection for agricultural studies?
Enablement.Answer: In the lysimeter setup, soil moisture sensors are placed at various depths (2cm, 10cm, 20cm, 40cm) along with temperature sensors at multiple soil layers (5cm, 30cm, 50cm, 100cm, 140cm) to capture detailed vertical profiles of soil conditions. This multi-layered data collection approach helps in understanding the soil-plant-atmosphere interactions comprehensively.

Expectation.Question: Why might the representativeness of data collection using lysimeters be limited in agricultural research?
Expectation.Answer: Lysimeters provide single-point observations with limited spatial representativeness, which is crucial in agricultural research where conditions can vary significantly across a field. Additionally, lysimeters can disrupt natural soil-plant-atmosphere interactions, leading to discrepancies in soil moisture and heat exchange compared to surrounding fields.

Expectation.Question: What factors could lead to discrepancies between evapotranspiration measurements collected by different methods such as lysimeters and eddy covariance systems?
Expectation.Answer: Discrepancies may arise because lysimeters can isolate the soil within them from external environmental exchanges, causing differences in water and heat dynamics compared to the external field. This isolation might result in higher soil temperatures and moisture within the lysimeter, leading to higher recorded evapotranspiration values compared to eddy covariance systems.

Expectation.Question: Why is it necessary to ensure consistent growth conditions within lysimeters and surrounding fields during data collection for crop studies?
Expectation.Answer: Consistent growth conditions are needed to ensure that the data collected within the lysimeters is representative of the surrounding fields. Variations in planting time, crop type, and maintenance can influence crop growth and evapotranspiration, potentially leading to biased or unrepresentative data if lysimeter conditions differ significantly from the surrounding agricultural area.

Judgmental.Question: How do you assess the impact of crop growth within lysimeters on the accuracy of evapotranspiration measurement, and what methodological strategies could be employed to mitigate any identified issues?
Judgmental.Answer: Crop growth within lysimeters significantly impacts evapotranspiration measurements due to isolation from surrounding soil conditions. This can lead to discrepancies in soil moisture and temperature. Methodological strategies to mitigate these issues could include calibrating lysimeter data with other measurements, such as eddy covariance, or adjusting for energy balance discrepancies to enhance accuracy.

Assertion.Question: I don’t understand why the spatial representativeness of a single-point observation method like lysimeter is considered limited in this domain?
Assertion.Answer: A single-point observation method such as a lysimeter is considered to have limited spatial representativeness because it only measures the evapotranspiration at its specific location, which may not accurately reflect the variability across a larger agricultural field or region. Factors like soil type, crop variety, and environmental conditions can vary across a field, leading to differences in evapotranspiration that are not captured by a single lysimeter.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential data collection methods that can complement lysimeter observations to enhance the understanding of evapotranspiration dynamics in agricultural fields.
Request/Directive.Answer: Complementary methods include using eddy covariance (EC) systems and automatic weather stations (AWS) to measure meteorological factors such as net radiation, air temperature, air humidity, and wind speed. These methods, when combined with lysimeter data, can provide a broader understanding of evapotranspiration dynamics and help verify the lysimeter's representativeness.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify and discuss the significance of datasets that can be utilized to study the seasonal variation of soil evaporation and crop evapotranspiration in North China agricultural regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: Datasets from lysimeter, eddy covariance, and automatic weather station measurements are significant as they provide insights into the daily and seasonal variations of soil evaporation and crop evapotranspiration. These datasets are crucial for analyzing the correlation between field evapotranspiration and meteorological factors, aiding in agricultural water management and decision-making.
